terms.definition: Other products from IPSpecialist LTD regarding CSP technology are:

Amazon CloudWatch is a monitoring and observability service that collects and tracks metrics, logs, and events from AWS resources and applications. It provides actionable insights to optimize performance and troubleshoot issues. Users can set alarms and create dashboards for real-time data visualization. CloudWatch integrates seamlessly with other AWS services to enhance operational efficiency.

Amazon DynamoDB is a fully managed NoSQL database service offering fast and flexible performance. It supports key-value and document data models, making it ideal for web, mobile, and gaming applications. DynamoDB automatically scales to handle high traffic while maintaining low latency. Its built-in security, backup, and restore features ensure data safety.

Amazon EBS is a block storage service designed for use with Amazon EC2 instances to provide persistent and highly available storage. It supports a wide range of workloads, including databases and enterprise applications. Users can choose between SSD and HDD options to meet performance and cost needs. Snapshots allow easy backup and disaster recovery.

Amazon EC2 offers scalable virtual servers in the cloud, enabling users to launch, stop, and manage compute instances as needed. It supports various operating systems and instance types to match different workloads. EC2 integrates with other AWS services to enhance functionality and scalability. Users can also implement auto-scaling and load balancing for dynamic demand.

Amazon Kinesis collects, processes, and analyzes real-time streaming data from various sources. It enables developers to build applications for video analytics, log monitoring, and more. Kinesis scales automatically to handle high data throughput. It also supports integration with AWS services for advanced analytics and machine learning workflows.

Amazon Redshift is a fully managed data warehouse service that allows fast and efficient querying of large datasets. It supports advanced SQL analytics and integrates with business intelligence tools. Redshift offers columnar storage and data compression to optimize performance. It is ideal for big data analytics, reporting, and data lake integrations.

Amazon RDS simplifies the setup, operation, and scaling of relational databases in the cloud. It supports multiple database engines, such as MySQL, PostgreSQL, and SQL Server. RDS automates time-consuming tasks like backups, software patching, and monitoring. It ensures high availability with multi-AZ deployments and read replicas for improved performance.

Amazon Route 53 is a scalable Domain Name System (DNS) and domain registration service. It routes end users to applications by translating domain names into IP addresses. Route 53 supports health checks to ensure traffic is directed to healthy endpoints. It integrates with AWS services for seamless cloud application management.

Amazon S3 is a scalable object storage service designed for any type of data, offering durability, security, and easy access. It is commonly used for backup, archiving, and content distribution. S3 provides lifecycle policies to automate data management. It supports encryption and access control to ensure data protection.

Amazon S3 Glacier is a low-cost storage service for long-term data archiving and backup. It offers retrieval options ranging from a few minutes to hours, depending on urgency. Glacier is highly secure and durable, making it suitable for regulatory compliance and infrequently accessed data. Its integration with S3 simplifies data management.

Amazon SNS is a messaging service that enables the sending of notifications to devices, applications, or other services. It supports pub/sub messaging patterns, allowing multiple subscribers to receive messages from a single topic. SNS is often used for application alerts, notifications, and mobile push messaging. It integrates with AWS Lambda for event-driven computing.

Amazon VPC provides an isolated network environment for deploying AWS resources securely. It allows users to define IP ranges, subnets, and route tables. VPC integrates with AWS security services like IAM and security groups to control access. It supports VPN and Direct Connect for secure communication with on-premises systems.

Amazon WorkSpaces is a managed desktop-as-a-service (DaaS) solution that delivers virtual desktops to users. It supports Windows and Linux environments, enabling remote work and collaboration. WorkSpaces simplifies desktop management with automated provisioning and updates. It integrates with AWS security and compliance services for data protection. AWS Artifact AWS Artifact is a central repository for accessing AWS security and compliance documents. It provides on-demand access to audit reports, certifications, and other compliance artifacts. Artifact helps organizations meet regulatory requirements by offering evidence of AWSâ€™s adherence to global standards. It simplifies compliance management and reporting.

AWS Auto Scaling automatically adjusts the compute resources to match changing demand. It ensures optimal performance and cost-efficiency by scaling up or down based on predefined policies. Auto Scaling supports applications hosted on EC2, ECS, and DynamoDB. It integrates with CloudWatch to trigger scaling actions based on real-time metrics.

AWS CloudFormation simplifies infrastructure management by enabling automated resource provisioning through templates. Users can define their infrastructure as code to replicate environments consistently. CloudFormation supports a wide range of AWS services, reducing manual configuration effort. It enables version control and auditing for resource changes.

AWS CloudFront is a content delivery network (CDN) that accelerates the distribution of data, videos, applications, and APIs globally. It caches content at edge locations to minimize latency and improve user experience. CloudFront integrates with AWS security services to protect against DDoS attacks and unauthorized access.

AWS CloudTrail records API calls and account activity across AWS services for governance and compliance. It provides detailed event logs to track changes and troubleshoot issues. CloudTrail supports real-time event monitoring and integrates with CloudWatch for alerting. It ensures accountability by enabling auditing of all AWS actions.

AWS Config tracks resource configurations and evaluates them against compliance policies. It provides a detailed inventory of AWS resources and their changes over time. Config enables automated compliance checks and remediation actions. It integrates with AWS security services to ensure a secure cloud environment.

AWS Control Tower simplifies the setup and governance of a secure multiaccount AWS environment. It provides pre-configured best practices, guardrails, and automation for account provisioning. Control Tower integrates with AWS Organizations to manage account structures. It offers visibility into policy compliance and operational activities.

AWS Direct Connect establishes a dedicated network connection between on-premises systems and AWS. It enhances data transfer performance and security by bypassing the public internet. Direct Connect supports hybrid cloud architectures, enabling seamless integration with AWS services. It reduces latency and ensures consistent network performance.

AWS Elastic Beanstalk simplifies application deployment by automating the provisioning of resources like EC2, RDS, and load balancers. Users can focus on code while Elastic Beanstalk handles scaling, monitoring, and updates. It supports multiple programming languages and frameworks. Beanstalk provides detailed health monitoring for applications.

AWS Elastic Load Balancing automatically distributes incoming traffic across multiple targets, such as EC2 instances or containers. It enhances application availability and fault tolerance by routing traffic to healthy resources. ELB supports various protocols, including HTTP, HTTPS, and TCP. It integrates with Auto Scaling to handle traffic surges.

AWS Fargate is a serverless compute engine for running containers without managing servers. It works with Amazon ECS and EKS to simplify containerized application deployment. Fargate handles provisioning and scaling, allowing developers to focus on application logic. It ensures consistent performance and integrates with AWS security services.

AWS Glue is a fully managed extract, transform, and load (ETL) service for preparing and moving data. It automates data discovery, schema inference, and job scheduling. Glue supports integration with data lakes and analytics services. It simplifies the process of transforming raw data into insights.

AWS IAM provides secure access control for AWS resources by managing users, groups, and roles. It enables fine-grained permissions to enforce the principle of least privilege. IAM supports multi-factor authentication (MFA) for enhanced security. It integrates with other AWS services to ensure consistent access management.

AWS Lambda is a serverless compute service that executes code in response to events. It eliminates the need to provision or manage servers, allowing developers to focus on functionality. Lambda scales automatically based on request volume. It integrates with various AWS services for event-driven application workflows.

AWS Outposts extends AWS infrastructure and services to on-premises environments. It supports hybrid cloud use cases by providing consistent APIs and tools across the cloud and on-premises. Outposts enable low- latency applications and data residency compliance. It integrates with other AWS services for seamless operation.

AWS Security Hub provides a centralized view of security alerts and compliance status across AWS accounts. It aggregates findings from multiple AWS services and third-party tools. Security Hub supports automated remediation and continuous compliance checks. It helps organizations maintain a secure cloud environment.

terms.term: AWS supports Kubernetes through Amazon EKS (Elastic Kubernetes
terms.definition: Service), providing a fully managed environment for running Kubernetes clusters on AWS infrastructure.

AWS Trusted Advisor offers real-time guidance to optimize AWS resource usage and improve security, performance, and cost-efficiency. It evaluates resources against AWS best practices and provides actionable recommendations. Trusted Advisor covers areas like fault tolerance, service limits, and cost optimization. It is a valuable tool for managing AWS environments effectively.

Backup refers to the process of copying data to protect it from loss or corruption. In AWS, services like AWS Backup allow users to automate the backup of AWS resources like Amazon EBS volumes, RDS databases, and Amazon DynamoDB tables to safeguard against data loss due to accidental deletion or disaster events.

Backup Plan is a set of rules and schedules defined by AWS Backup to automate the backup process. It includes the frequency of backups (daily, weekly, etc.) and the retention period (how long the backups are stored) to ensure compliance and data protection.

Backup Vault is a centralized repository within AWS Backup where backups are stored and managed. It provides a secure location for backup data and supports features like encryption, lifecycle management, and access control.

The Basic Support Plan is a free support plan provided to all AWS accounts. It includes access to AWS billing support, customer service, and documentation but does not provide technical support for AWS services.

A Bastion Host is a security host that acts as an intermediary between a public network and a private network, often deployed in a Virtual Private Cloud (VPC). It is used to securely access instances in private subnets by connecting through the bastion host, typically using SSH or RDP. Batch Job A Batch Job is a compute task that is processed in batch mode, usually involving large amounts of data. AWS services like AWS Batch enable the orchestration and execution of batch jobs at scale, automating the resource provisioning and job execution process.

Batch Processing is the execution of large-scale data processing tasks, where tasks are grouped together into batches. AWS Batch is a fully managed service that facilitates batch job execution by dynamically provisioning the required compute resources and managing the processing workflow.

Big Data refers to extremely large datasets that cannot be processed efficiently with traditional data management tools. AWS provides services like Amazon EMR (Elastic MapReduce), which can handle big data processing using frameworks like Hadoop and Spark.

Billing & Cost Management is a set of AWS tools that help users track, manage, and optimize their cloud costs. This includes features like cost allocation, usage tracking, and generating detailed reports to monitor AWS spending.

Billing & Usage Reports are detailed reports available through AWS Cost Explorer that provide insights into AWS spending and usage patterns. These reports help users understand cost trends and identify opportunities for cost optimization.

Billing Alerts are notifications set up through AWS Budgets to alert users when their AWS spending exceeds predefined thresholds. This helps users keep track of their costs and avoid unexpected overages.

The Billing Dashboard in the AWS Management Console provides a comprehensive overview of your AWS accountâ€™s billing information, cost trends, usage reports, and payment history. It serves as a central location to track spending.

Billing Reports provide detailed information about the costs associated with AWS services, available through the AWS Cost and Usage Reports. These reports allow users to break down their usage and costs by service, region, and resource.

Binary Large Object (Blob) refers to a collection of binary data, often used for storing unstructured data like images, videos, or large documents. In AWS, Amazon S3 is commonly used to store blobs due to its scalable, durable storage capabilities.

Block Device Mapping is the configuration that specifies how Amazon EBS (Elastic Block Store) volumes are attached to EC2 instances. This mapping defines the device names and volume sizes, enabling EC2 instances to use block-level storage.

Block Storage is a storage method where data is stored in fixed-size blocks. AWS provides Amazon EBS as a block storage solution that can be attached to EC2 instances for persistent storage needs. Block storage is ideal for applications that require high-performance, low-latency access to data.

Blockchain is a distributed ledger technology that allows secure, transparent, and immutable record-keeping. AWS provides Amazon Managed Blockchain, a fully managed service that allows businesses to set up and manage blockchain networks for applications like supply chain tracking and financial transactions.

Blueprints are preconfigured templates in AWS Lightsail that allow users to quickly deploy applications or development stacks. These blueprints include popular software like WordPress, LAMP stacks, and more, enabling rapid provisioning of cloud environments.

Bootstrapping refers to the process of automatically configuring an EC2 instance when it starts. This can include tasks like installing software, updating configurations, and setting up environment variables. Bootstrapping is often achieved using user data scripts or configuration management tools.

Browser-Based Access refers to using a web browser to access and manage AWS resources. The AWS Management Console provides a browser-based interface for interacting with AWS services, offering a user-friendly environment for configuring and monitoring cloud resources.

A Bucket is a container in Amazon S3 used to store and organize objects. Buckets allow users to manage and secure their data with access policies and lifecycle rules. Each bucket is globally unique, and data stored within buckets can be easily retrieved, uploaded, or deleted.

Bucket Access Control involves mechanisms like IAM roles, bucket policies, and ACLs (Access Control Lists) that manage access permissions for Amazon S3 buckets. These controls determine who can read, write, or modify data within the bucket.

A Bucket Policy is a JSON document that defines permissions for an Amazon S3 bucket. It allows fine-grained control over who can access the contents of the bucket and what actions they can perform, such as reading, writing, or deleting objects.

A Build Artifact is the output of a build process, such as binaries, libraries, or deployable files. These artifacts are often stored in Amazon S3 for easy access during deployment and to maintain version control.

Burstable Instances are EC2 instance types that provide baseline performance but can temporarily exceed their baseline using burst credits. These credits accumulate during periods of low utilization and can be used during periods of high demand, providing cost savings for workloads with variable CPU needs.

Burstable Performance Instances are EC2 instance types designed for workloads that experience variable CPU demands. These instances offer baseline performance and allow users to burst to higher performance levels when needed. The performance is governed by burst credits that accumulate when the instance is underutilized.

A Business Associate Agreement (BAA) is a legal contract between AWS and its customers that outlines the terms and conditions for handling HIPAA (Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act)-protected data. Organizations in the healthcare industry must ensure compliance when using AWS for storing or processing sensitive health data.

Business Continuity refers to the practices, policies, and processes that ensure critical business functions can continue operating during and after a disaster or unexpected event. AWS provides resilience solutions like AWS Backup, Cross-Region Replication, and Amazon Route 53 to help businesses maintain continuity.

The Business Support Plan is an AWS support offering that provides 24/7 technical support, including architectural guidance and proactive monitoring. This plan is designed for businesses with mission-critical workloads requiring fast response times and expert advice.

BYOL (Bring Your Own License) is a licensing model that allows customers to use their existing software licenses in AWS environments. This model can help reduce costs for customers who already own software licenses for applications like Microsoft Windows Server, SQL Server, or other third-party software. AWS supports BYOL through services like AWS License Manager.
CCDA Study Guide

AWS Certificate Manager (ACM) is a service that helps manage SSL/TLS certificates for websites and applications hosted on AWS. It automates the process of provisioning, managing, and deploying certificates to secure communications over the internet. ACM can also integrate with other AWS services like Elastic Load Balancing (ELB) and CloudFront to simplify the management of secure connections.

AWS CLI (Command Line Interface) is a unified tool that enables users to interact with AWS services from the command line. It simplifies the automation and scripting of AWS operations, offering the same functionality as the AWS Management Console but in a text-based interface. This tool is ideal for developers and system administrators who need to automate routine tasks or manage services remotely.

Cloud Computing refers to the delivery of computing services (like storage, processing power, databases, networking, and more) over the internet, on a pay-as-you-go basis. AWS provides a wide range of cloud services that allow businesses to scale resources on demand, eliminating the need for large upfront investments in hardware and infrastructure.

Cloud Migration is the process of moving data, applications, or workloads from on-premises infrastructure to the cloud. This can involve rehosting, replatforming, or refactoring applications to be cloud-native. AWS provides various tools, like AWS Migration Hub and AWS Database Migration Service, to streamline and accelerate the migration process. Cloud9 AWS Cloud9 is an integrated development environment (IDE) that runs in the cloud, enabling developers to write, run, and debug code from a web browser. It supports multiple programming languages and integrates with AWS services, making it easier for developers to work on cloud applications without needing to set up a local development environment.

CloudEndure is an AWS disaster recovery service that helps businesses replicate and recover workloads across AWS regions. It provides continuous data replication and automated failover to ensure minimal downtime in the event of a disaster. This service is particularly useful for critical workloads that need to be quickly restored after a failure.

CloudFormation Stack is a collection of AWS resources that are created, updated, or deleted together as a single unit through AWS CloudFormation. A stack is defined by a CloudFormation template, which specifies the AWS resources and configurations that need to be deployed, ensuring infrastructure consistency and repeatability.

CloudFormation Template is a JSON or YAML file that defines the AWS resources, their properties, and relationships for creating a CloudFormation stack. Templates provide a way to automate the deployment of AWS resources, ensuring consistent and version-controlled infrastructure setups.

CloudFront Edge Location is a global network of data centers used by Amazon CloudFront to cache copies of web content closer to end-users. This reduces latency and improves the speed of content delivery for websites, media streaming, and other web applications. CloudFront Origin CloudFront Origin is the source of content that is distributed through Amazon CloudFront, such as an S3 bucket, an HTTP server, or an Elastic Load Balancer. CloudFront retrieves content from the origin and caches it at edge locations to speed up delivery to users.

AWS CloudHSM is a hardware security module (HSM) service that helps manage and safeguard cryptographic keys in dedicated hardware. It provides a secure environment for running cryptographic operations, ensuring compliance with various industry standards like FIPS 140-2.

AWS CloudShell is a browser-based shell environment that provides a command-line interface for managing AWS resources. It is pre-configured with AWS CLI and other tools, allowing users to quickly interact with AWS services directly from the browser without needing to install software locally.

CloudTrail Event History is a feature within AWS CloudTrail that records the API calls made to AWS services. It provides a comprehensive audit trail of user and service activities, helping with security analysis, operational troubleshooting, and compliance monitoring.

CloudTrail Insights is a feature of AWS CloudTrail that automatically detects unusual API activities within an AWS account. By identifying potential security risks or operational anomalies, CloudTrail Insights helps improve security posture and manage AWS resources more effectively.

Amazon CloudWatch Alarms are used to monitor the health and performance of AWS resources. Alarms trigger notifications or automated actions when metrics, such as CPU utilization or disk I/O, exceed predefined thresholds. This helps ensure timely responses to performance issues or resource anomalies.

Amazon CloudWatch Logs is a service that allows users to monitor, store, and access log files from various AWS resources. These logs can provide valuable insights into application behavior, security events, and operational performance.

A Cluster is a group of linked or similar resources working together to accomplish a task, such as an ECS (Elastic Container Service) cluster for running containers or an EKS (Elastic Kubernetes Service) cluster for managing Kubernetes-based applications. Clusters provide scalability and fault tolerance by distributing workloads across multiple resources.

Amazon Cognito User Pools is a managed service that provides authentication and authorization for web and mobile applications. It allows developers to create and manage secure user directories, handle user sign-ups and sign-ins, and integrate with social identity providers like Google or Facebook.

Cold Storage refers to data storage that is optimized for infrequent access and long-term retention. In AWS, Amazon S3 Glacier and S3 Glacier Deep Archive are cold storage solutions, ideal for data that is rarely accessed but needs to be securely stored for extended periods.

Compliance in the context of AWS refers to ensuring that AWS resources and workloads adhere to industry regulations, standards, and best practices. AWS offers tools like AWS Artifact and AWS Config to help organizations manage and monitor compliance with various frameworks such as GDPR, HIPAA, and PCI-DSS.

Compute Resources are services that provide processing power in the cloud, such as Amazon EC2 (Elastic Compute Cloud) for virtual machines and AWS Lambda for serverless computing. These resources allow applications to run without the need for on-premises infrastructure.

Container Orchestration is the automated deployment, scaling, and management of containerized applications. AWS provides Amazon ECS (Elastic Container Service) and Amazon EKS (Elastic Kubernetes Service) as managed services for container orchestration, simplifying the process of running containerized workloads at scale.

A Content Delivery Network (CDN) is a system of distributed servers that cache and deliver web content, such as images, videos, or HTML pages, to users based on their geographic location. Amazon CloudFront is AWS's CDN service, designed to improve the speed and performance of content delivery.

AWS Control Tower is a service that provides a centralized dashboard to govern multi-account AWS environments. It automates the setup of AWS accounts, applying best practices, policies, and guardrails to ensure that organizations maintain compliance, security, and proper resource management.

Cost Allocation Tags are metadata labels that can be applied to AWS resources to track and allocate costs. By tagging resources according to project, department, or environment, organizations can more easily analyze and manage their AWS spending in services like Cost Explorer and AWS Budgets.

AWS Cost Explorer is a tool that enables users to visualize, analyze, and manage AWS spending. It provides detailed insights into usage patterns, cost allocation, and trends over time, helping businesses optimize their AWS costs and budgeting.

Cost Optimization involves strategies to reduce AWS spending, such as rightsizing resources, using spot instances, and optimizing storage. AWS provides tools like AWS Trusted Advisor, Cost Explorer, and AWS Compute Optimizer to help organizations identify areas where they can reduce costs.

Cross-Account Access is a feature of AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) that allows users or roles from one AWS account to access resources in another account. This is useful for sharing resources, delegating administrative duties, or managing multiple AWS accounts securely.

Cross-Region Replication (CRR) is an Amazon S3 feature that automatically replicates objects between S3 buckets in different AWS regions. CRR is used for disaster recovery, data residency requirements, and ensuring availability across regions.

A Customer Gateway is a customer-managed device or software application that establishes a secure VPN (Virtual Private Network) connection to an AWS Virtual Private Cloud (VPC). It acts as the on-premises endpoint in a VPN connection, enabling secure communication between on-premises networks and AWS resources.

Data Analytics is the process of examining and analyzing data to uncover patterns, trends, and insights that can drive decision-making. AWS offers various services for data analytics, such as Amazon Glue for ETL (Extract, Transform, Load), Amazon Redshift for data warehousing and complex queries, and Amazon Athena for serverless query execution on data stored in Amazon S3.

Data Compression involves reducing the size of data files to optimize storage and reduce data transfer costs. In AWS, compression techniques are often used in Amazon S3 to lower storage costs for large datasets and speed up the transfer of data, especially for big data workloads.

Data Encryption is the process of encoding data to prevent unauthorized access, ensuring data privacy and integrity. AWS uses AWS Key Management Service (KMS) for managing encryption keys, enabling encryption at rest (for data stored on disk) and in transit (for data transmitted across networks).

Data Lakes are large, centralized repositories for storing vast amounts of raw, unstructured, or semi-structured data at scale. These lakes facilitate the aggregation of data from multiple sources, making it available for analysis and machine learning. AWS implements data lakes using Amazon S3, where data can be stored and processed.

Data Lifecycle Management is the practice of applying automated policies to manage data through its lifecycle. In AWS, this is often applied to Amazon S3, where data is moved between different storage classes (e.g., S3 Standard, S3 Glacier) based on usage patterns, optimizing cost and performance.

Data Pipeline is an AWS service used for processing, transforming, and moving data between different AWS services. It helps automate complex data workflows and manage the flow of data from sources to destinations, making it easier to build scalable data processing systems.

Data Replication refers to the process of copying data from one location to another to ensure redundancy and high availability. AWS uses data replication in services like Amazon RDS and Amazon S3, ensuring data is duplicated across multiple availability zones or regions for fault tolerance.

Data Retrieval Policy is used in Amazon S3 Glacier storage, defining the speed and cost of retrieving data stored in the Glacier or Glacier Deep Archive storage classes. Users can specify retrieval options to optimize costs based on how urgently they need to access archived data.

Data Sync is an AWS service that simplifies the process of transferring data between on-premises storage systems and AWS storage services like Amazon S3, Amazon EFS, and Amazon FSx. It can accelerate large-scale data migrations and is ideal for periodic backups or large data transfers.

Data Transfer involves moving data within or outside of AWS. Data transfer costs in AWS depend on the source, destination, and amount of data moved. AWS Direct Connect and AWS Snowball are some of the options available to reduce transfer costs and improve performance for large datasets.

A Data Warehouse is a centralized repository designed to store large volumes of structured data, typically for analytics and reporting purposes. Amazon Redshift is a fully managed data warehouse solution that enables fast query performance on large datasets and integrates with AWS analytics tools.

DDoS Protection refers to measures taken to protect resources from distributed denial-of-service attacks, which aim to overwhelm and disrupt services. AWS provides AWS Shield for automatic DDoS protection and AWS WAF (Web Application Firewall) to filter malicious traffic and protect web applications.

A Dedicated Host is a physical server within AWS that is fully dedicated to a single customer, offering the ability to meet specific compliance and licensing requirements. This option is often chosen for applications with strict hardware isolation or those requiring specific licensing arrangements.

A Dedicated Instance is an EC2 instance that runs on hardware dedicated to a single customer, providing more isolation compared to regular EC2 instances. It is ideal for workloads requiring additional security, compliance, or isolation but still benefiting from the flexibility of the AWS cloud.

Deduplication is the process of eliminating duplicate data to save storage space. In AWS, deduplication is supported in services like AWS Backup and Amazon S3, where identical data blocks or files are removed, reducing storage costs and improving data management efficiency. Deployment Deployment is the process of releasing or updating applications, services, or infrastructure in AWS. AWS provides a variety of tools to automate deployments, such as AWS Elastic Beanstalk, AWS CodePipeline, and AWS CloudFormation, which simplify the management and deployment of applications.

Developer Tools is a suite of services provided by AWS to enable DevOps processes, helping developers and teams automate the development, testing, and deployment of applications. Key tools include AWS CodeCommit, AWS CodeBuild, AWS CodeDeploy, and AWS CodePipeline, which streamline the software development lifecycle.

DevOps is a set of practices that combines software development (Dev) and IT operations (Ops) to automate infrastructure, streamline software delivery, and improve collaboration between development and operations teams. AWS provides a wide range of services, such as AWS CodePipeline and AWS CloudFormation, to support DevOps workflows.

Direct Attach refers to a storage configuration in which storage devices are directly attached to EC2 instances to provide low-latency, high-speed access. This is commonly used for high-performance computing or storage-intensive applications where data must be accessed rapidly.

AWS Direct Connect is a dedicated, private network connection between onpremises data centers and AWS. It provides high-bandwidth, low-latency, and more secure connectivity to AWS, bypassing the public internet, and making it ideal for mission-critical applications, data migrations, and hybrid cloud architectures. Directory Service AWS Directory Service is a managed service that enables AWS customers to set up and run Microsoft Active Directory (AD) on AWS. It simplifies the integration of AWS resources with on-premises AD environments and also offers Simple AD, a managed directory for smaller environments.

Disk I/O (Input/Output) measures the performance of disk operations, such as reading from or writing to storage devices. In AWS, EC2 instances and EBS volumes are evaluated by metrics like throughput and IOPS (input/output operations per second), which influence workload efficiency.

Distributed Computing is the practice of using multiple interconnected computers or systems to perform tasks that would be too resource-intensive for a single machine. AWS provides services like EC2, ECS, and Lambda to implement distributed computing architectures, enabling scalability and fault tolerance.

Database Migration Service (DMS) is a fully managed service that helps migrate databases to AWS with minimal downtime. DMS supports migrating data from on-premises databases to AWS, from one AWS database to another, or between different database engines, ensuring data consistency throughout the process.

Docker is a platform that enables the packaging of applications and their dependencies into lightweight containers. These containers can run on any environment that supports Docker, including AWS services like Amazon ECS and Amazon EKS, providing portability, scalability, and consistency for applications. DocumentDB Amazon DocumentDB is a managed document database service designed to store and scale JSON data. It is compatible with MongoDB, making it easy for MongoDB users to migrate applications to AWS without changes to their application code. DocumentDB is used for web and mobile applications that require flexible schema and scalability.

DNS is a system that translates domain names (e.g., www.example.com) into IP addresses that computers can use to locate resources on the internet. AWS provides Amazon Route 53, a scalable DNS and domain name registration service, which helps manage the routing of internet traffic to AWS resources.

Durability refers to the ability of a storage system to protect data from loss or corruption. In AWS, services like Amazon S3 are designed for high durability, with 11 nines of durability (99.999999999%), ensuring that stored data remains intact even in the event of hardware failures.

Dynamic Content is content that is generated or personalized in real-time based on user interactions or data rather than being static. In AWS, Amazon CloudFront can be used to deliver dynamic content quickly to end-users by caching static elements while dynamically generating and serving content as needed.

DynamoDB is a fully managed, fast, and scalable NoSQL database service provided by AWS. It is designed for applications that require low-latency data access and the ability to scale horizontally. DynamoDB supports keyvalue and document data models and is often used for high-traffic web and mobile applications.

terms.term: DynamoDB read/write throughput. These metrics are tracked via
terms.definition: CloudWatch for monitoring and optimization.

An EBS Snapshot is a point-in-time backup of an Elastic Block Store (EBS) volume, providing data protection and disaster recovery. Snapshots are incremental, meaning only changes since the last snapshot are saved, making them efficient in terms of storage. Snapshots are stored in Amazon S3, ensuring durability and availability for restoring volumes or migrating data.

An EC2 Instance is a virtual server in AWS that can be launched and managed to run applications. EC2 instances come in various sizes, performance levels, and configurations, allowing users to select the optimal compute resources for their needs. They are the fundamental building blocks for cloud-based applications in AWS.

ECS is a fully managed container orchestration service that enables users to run and scale Docker containers on AWS. ECS integrates with other AWS services, such as Elastic Load Balancing and IAM, to facilitate container management and deployment, supporting both long-running applications and microservices architectures.

An Edge Location is a site used by Amazon CloudFront to cache copies of content closer to end-users. By reducing the distance between users and the content they request, edge locations help decrease latency and improve the speed of content delivery. These locations are spread globally for faster access to static and dynamic content.

Egress refers to the outbound data transfer from AWS resources, such as EC2 instances or S3 buckets, to destinations outside of AWS (like the internet). Egress is typically associated with data transfer costs, and AWS provides pricing details for outbound data across different regions.

EKS is a managed service that simplifies the process of running Kubernetes clusters on AWS. It takes care of the complexity of cluster management, such as control plane provisioning, security patching, and scaling, allowing users to focus on deploying and managing containerized applications.

Elastic Beanstalk is a Platform-as-a-Service (PaaS) offering that simplifies the deployment, management, and scaling of web applications. Developers can upload their code, and Elastic Beanstalk automatically handles infrastructure provisioning, load balancing, scaling, and monitoring, enabling easy application management.

Elastic Cache is a fully managed in-memory caching service that supports popular caching engines like Redis and Memcached. It helps improve application performance by storing frequently accessed data in memory, reducing latency and improving response times for read-heavy workloads.

Elastic File System (EFS) is a fully managed, scalable file storage service designed for use with Amazon EC2 instances. EFS provides a simple, elastic file system that can automatically scale as storage needs grow, offering shared access to files from multiple EC2 instances across availability zones.

Elastic GPU is a service that allows users to attach GPU resources to EC2 instances to enhance graphics performance. This is especially useful for applications that require high-performance graphics rendering, such as gaming, 3D visualization, or machine learning workloads. Elastic IP (EIP) An Elastic IP (EIP) is a static, public IPv4 address that is designed for dynamic cloud computing. EIPs allow users to associate a static IP with an EC2 instance or other AWS resources, and they can be remapped to another instance if needed for failover or disaster recovery.

Elastic Load Balancing (ELB) is a service that automatically distributes incoming application traffic across multiple EC2 instances, ensuring high availability and fault tolerance. ELB supports three types of load balancers: Application Load Balancer (ALB), Network Load Balancer (NLB), and Classic Load Balancer (CLB).

Elastic MapReduce (EMR) is a fully managed cluster platform that simplifies the processing of big data using frameworks like Apache Hadoop, Spark, and Hive. EMR allows users to scale processing capacity easily and integrate with other AWS services like S3, Redshift, and Athena.

The Elastic Network Adapter (ENA) is a high-performance network interface designed for EC2 instances. It enables enhanced networking by providing low latency, high throughput, and high packet-per-second performance, supporting workloads that require network-intensive operations.

An Elastic Network Interface (ENI) is a virtual network interface that can be attached to EC2 instances for network connectivity. It provides multiple IP addresses, security groups, and network interfaces for EC2 instances, allowing for flexible network configurations and high availability setups.

Elastic Transcoder is a media transcoding service that allows users to convert media files into formats optimized for different devices. It supports a variety of input and output formats and can automatically scale based on the transcoding workload, making it ideal for video streaming applications.

Elasticity is the ability of cloud resources to scale up or down based on demand. This core feature of cloud computing allows applications and services to automatically adjust their resource allocation, ensuring optimal performance during high demand and cost savings during periods of low usage.

Elasticsearch Service is a fully managed service that enables users to deploy, operate, and scale Elasticsearch clusters for real-time search, logging, and analytics. It integrates with other AWS services like Kinesis, CloudWatch, and Lambda, allowing users to analyze large volumes of log or event data.

Encryption at Rest refers to the process of securing data stored on disk by encrypting it. AWS provides encryption options for services like Amazon S3, EBS, and RDS, using either AWS-managed or customer-managed encryption keys to ensure data confidentiality and compliance with security standards.

Encryption in Transit protects data as it moves between services or between an AWS resource and an external system. This is typically achieved using secure protocols like SSL/TLS to prevent data interception and ensure the privacy and integrity of information in transit.

An Encryption Key is a cryptographic key used to encrypt and decrypt data. AWS provides AWS Key Management Service (KMS) for creating, managing, and controlling the use of encryption keys, enabling users to protect sensitive data stored in AWS services and comply with encryption standards.

An Endpoint is a connection point for accessing AWS services, typically in the form of an API. AWS services like Amazon S3 or Amazon EC2 have endpoints that allow users to interact with the service using HTTP requests, enabling programmatic access to AWS resources.

Endpoint Protection involves security measures that safeguard devices (e.g., computers, mobile devices) connected to AWS resources. This includes technologies like antivirus software, firewalls, and encryption to protect against threats that may affect endpoints accessing AWS environments.

Enhanced Networking is a feature that improves network performance for EC2 instances by providing high throughput, low latency, and lower jitter. It uses technologies like Elastic Network Adapter (ENA) and Intel 82599 VF to provide optimized networking capabilities for demanding applications.

Environment Variables are key-value pairs used in EC2 instances, AWS Lambda, or containers to store configuration settings and application parameters. They enable flexible and dynamic application behavior without requiring hardcoded values in the application code.

ETL is a data processing approach that involves extracting data from sources, transforming it into a suitable format, and loading it into a target system like a data warehouse. AWS provides AWS Glue, a fully managed ETL service, to automate these processes for large-scale data integration. Event Source Mapping Event Source Mapping is a Lambda configuration that connects event sources such as Amazon SQS, DynamoDB Streams, or Kinesis to a Lambda function. This enables automatic invocation of functions based on events in AWS services, supporting event-driven architectures.

EventBridge is a serverless event bus that allows users to route events from various sources (e.g., AWS services, SaaS applications) to AWS services or custom applications. It simplifies event-driven architecture by enabling easy integration and event routing without managing infrastructure.

An Exabyte is a unit of digital information storage equal to one billion gigabytes (1,000,000 terabytes). It is often used when discussing massive amounts of data in cloud computing, such as in the context of big data processing, storage solutions, and data lakes.

An Execution Role is an IAM role that grants AWS services the necessary permissions to perform actions on behalf of a user or application. For example, a Lambda function may need an execution role to access S3 or DynamoDB during execution, allowing it to interact with other AWS resources securely.

Failover refers to the automatic switching to a redundant or standby system when the primary system fails. This ensures high availability and resilience of applications, minimizing downtime. AWS services like Route 53 and Elastic Load Balancing offer failover capabilities to ensure continuous service availability during system failures.

Fargate is a serverless compute engine for containers provided by AWS. It allows you to run Docker containers without managing the underlying infrastructure (EC2 instances). You simply define the CPU and memory requirements, and AWS Fargate takes care of the rest, automatically provisioning and scaling the compute resources.

Fast Snapshot Restore (FSR) is a feature in Amazon Elastic Block Store (EBS) that accelerates the recovery of data from snapshots. FSR allows you to quickly initialize an EBS snapshot, reducing the time it takes to restore large volumes and improving recovery time objectives (RTO) for critical workloads.

Fast Track to Cloud refers to AWS training and certification resources aimed at accelerating the cloud adoption process for new users. It provides a structured path for users to quickly gain the knowledge and skills needed to work with AWS services and start deploying cloud-based solutions.

Fault Domains are logical groupings within an Availability Zone (AZ) that prevent single points of failure. In AWS, fault domains are used to ensure that infrastructure failures do not impact the entire AZ. For example, instances or services can be spread across multiple fault domains to increase resilience.

Fault Injection involves intentionally introducing failures into an application or system to test its resilience and response to disruptions. AWS Fault Injection Simulator is a service that allows users to simulate various types of failures, such as server crashes or network issues, to validate the robustness of applications.

Fault Tolerance is the ability of a system or application to continue operating smoothly even when one or more components fail. AWS provides fault tolerance features like auto-scaling, redundant data storage, and multi-AZ deployments to ensure that applications can withstand infrastructure failures and continue operating.

Federated Access is a method of allowing users to log in to AWS using credentials from an external identity provider (IdP). This eliminates the need to manage AWS credentials manually and integrates AWS with enterprise systems or third-party authentication providers.

Federated Identity refers to a method of using an external identity provider, such as Active Directory or Google Identity, to authenticate and authorize users to access AWS resources. This allows organizations to manage users across different platforms and federate access to AWS based on existing identity management systems.

Federated Login is a form of authentication that allows users to log in to AWS using credentials from a business or social identity provider (such as Google, Microsoft, or Facebook). AWS integrates with these providers to authenticate users without requiring separate AWS credentials.

Federated Security involves integrating AWS IAM with external identity providers to enable secure, cross-platform authentication. By using federated security, organizations can centralize access control and reduce the management overhead associated with user credentials in AWS.

File Gateway is an AWS Storage Gateway configuration that enables applications to access cloud-based file storage through standard file protocols (NFS or SMB). It allows on-premises applications to read and write to Amazon S3 as if it were a file system, enabling seamless cloud integration for file-based workloads.

File Storage refers to systems designed to store files and provide access to them over a network. AWS offers services like Elastic File System (EFS) that provide scalable and accessible file storage for EC2 instances and other applications, allowing for shared access to files with high availability and durability.

File System Backup refers to the process of creating copies of file systems to protect against data loss or corruption. AWS Backup integrates with Amazon EFS to automate the backup of file systems, ensuring that data is safely stored and can be restored when needed.

File System Caching is the practice of storing frequently accessed data in memory to reduce retrieval times and improve performance. This is typically used in conjunction with AWS services like Amazon EFS or Amazon FSx to enhance file access speeds.

Financial Forecasting refers to predicting future cloud spending based on historical usage patterns. AWS Cost Explorer and AWS Budgets allow users to forecast their spending and create financial reports, helping organizations manage their cloud budgets and avoid unexpected costs.

Financial Reports in AWS provide detailed billing and usage information to help organizations understand and manage their cloud costs. AWS Cost Explorer and AWS Billing and Cost Management tools generate reports that give insights into how resources are being utilized and how costs are being incurred.

Amazon Kinesis Firehose is a service that allows for the loading of streaming data into various AWS storage and analytics services. It automatically scales to match the throughput of incoming data and can stream data directly into services like Amazon S3, Amazon Redshift, or Amazon Elasticsearch for real-time analysis.

A Firewall is a security system that monitors and controls incoming and outgoing network traffic based on predefined rules. AWS provides firewall capabilities through Security Groups and Network ACLs, allowing you to control the flow of traffic to EC2 instances and other resources.

Firewall Manager is an AWS security management service that enables centralized configuration and management of firewall rules across multiple accounts and resources in AWS. It allows organizations to apply consistent firewall rules for resources such as EC2 instances and load balancers.

A Fleet refers to a group of resources, such as EC2 instances or servers, that are managed together to support scaling applications. AWS offers fleet management tools like Auto Scaling and Elastic Load Balancing to manage fleets of resources and ensure optimal performance.

Flexible Workloads are applications that can scale up or down to meet varying levels of demand. AWS services like Auto Scaling and Elastic Load Balancing support flexible workloads by automatically adjusting the number of resources to match the application's needs at any given time.

Flow Control refers to managing the flow of data within networks to ensure that traffic does not become congested and that resources are used efficiently. In AWS, flow control is essential for optimizing network performance, particularly for high-volume services like Amazon VPC and AWS Direct Connect.

Flow Logs are logs generated by Amazon VPC that capture information about the IP traffic going to and from network interfaces within a VPC. Flow logs can be used for troubleshooting, monitoring network traffic, and ensuring security compliance.

Forecasting API is part of Amazon Forecast, a service for generating timeseries predictions based on historical data. The Forecasting API enables users to integrate forecasting capabilities into their applications, helping with demand planning, resource allocation, and budgeting. Free Space Monitoring Free Space Monitoring refers to tracking storage usage and the amount of available space in AWS resources, such as EBS volumes and S3 buckets. AWS tools like CloudWatch help monitor storage space, trigger alerts when space is running low, and prevent issues related to resource constraints.

The Free Tier is an AWS offering that provides new users with limited free access to a variety of AWS services for a year or on a limited-use basis. It allows users to try out services like EC2, S3, and Lambda within predefined usage limits without incurring costs.

Fully Managed services in AWS are those where AWS takes care of the underlying infrastructure, operations, and maintenance tasks. This includes services like Amazon RDS, AWS Lambda, and Amazon S3, where users can focus solely on their applications without worrying about infrastructure management.

Function as a Service (FaaS) is a serverless computing model where users can run individual functions or code snippets in response to events without managing the underlying infrastructure. AWS Lambda is a prime example of FaaS, enabling users to execute code in response to triggers like HTTP requests, changes in data, or schedules.

Function Execution Time refers to the maximum duration that a Lambda function can run. By default, the execution time is limited to 15 minutes, after which the function is terminated if not completed. This limit helps ensure efficient use of AWS resources and allows for optimal scaling.

GameLift is a managed service by AWS designed to deploy, operate, and scale dedicated game servers for multiplayer games. It simplifies game server management by providing auto-scaling, matchmaking, and analytics, enabling game developers to focus on game development while AWS handles server infrastructure.

A Gateway Endpoint is a VPC endpoint that provides secure, private access to Amazon S3 and DynamoDB without requiring an internet gateway or NAT device. This allows for better security and performance when accessing these services from within a VPC.

Gateway Load Balancer simplifies the deployment and management of virtual appliances in AWS by distributing traffic across multiple appliances, such as firewalls, intrusion detection systems, or network traffic analyzers. It enables scaling and monitoring of these appliances while maintaining high availability.

General Purpose Instances in AWS EC2 provide a balanced mix of compute, memory, and networking resources. They are suitable for a wide variety of workloads, including web servers, development environments, and small to medium-sized databases. Examples include the t3 and m5 instance families.

Geo-Location Restrictions refer to the ability to restrict access to AWS resources based on a user's geographic location. This feature is available in services like Amazon CloudFront, which can block or allow traffic from certain countries or regions based on IP address geolocation.

Geo-Redundant Storage involves replicating data across geographically separated locations, ensuring high availability and durability. AWS services like Amazon S3 can be configured for geo-redundancy to protect against regional failures or disasters by storing data in multiple regions.

Geo-Targeting is the practice of delivering content to users based on their geographic location. AWS services like Amazon CloudFront support geotargeting by enabling content delivery that is tailored to specific regions, improving load times and user experience for localized content.

Amazon Glacier is a low-cost storage service designed for long-term data archiving and backup. It provides secure, durable, and highly available storage, but data retrieval times are slower compared to other S3 storage classes, making it ideal for infrequent access to archived data.

Glacier Deep Archive is an Amazon S3 storage class specifically designed for the lowest-cost storage of infrequently accessed data. It is ideal for longterm retention of data that is rarely accessed, such as legal or regulatory records, and offers the lowest price in S3.

Global Accelerator is a networking service that improves the availability and performance of applications by routing traffic through AWSâ€™s global network infrastructure. It reduces latency and increases reliability by directing users to the nearest healthy endpoint using anycast.

Global Infrastructure refers to the worldwide network of AWS data centers, regions, and availability zones. This infrastructure enables AWS to provide scalable, highly available, and fault-tolerant services to customers across the globe.

Global Reach refers to AWS's ability to provide services and resources across multiple geographical regions. This global presence enables businesses to deploy applications closer to users, ensuring better performance and compliance with regional data laws.

A Global Secondary Index (GSI) is a feature in Amazon DynamoDB that enables you to query data based on non-primary key attributes. GSIs allow you to perform efficient queries on attributes that are not part of the tableâ€™s primary key, improving query flexibility.

A Global Table in Amazon DynamoDB is a multi-region, fully replicated table designed to provide high availability and durability for globally distributed applications. Global Tables enable data to be automatically replicated across multiple regions, ensuring low-latency reads and writes.

AWS Glue is a fully managed extract, transform, and load (ETL) service that enables you to discover, prepare, and transform data for analytics. It integrates with services like Amazon S3, Redshift, and Athena, providing an easy way to manage data lakes and data workflows.

A Glue Crawler is a tool in AWS Glue that scans data in storage locations like Amazon S3 to infer schema and populate the data catalog. This simplifies the process of data discovery and indexing, making it easier to query and transform data without manually defining the schema.

The Glue Data Catalog is a metadata repository in AWS Glue that stores information about data in various AWS storage services. It enables you to query data in Amazon S3, Amazon Redshift Spectrum, and other services using AWS Athena and serves as a centralized metadata store.

A Golden AMI is a standardized Amazon Machine Image (AMI) used to ensure consistent configurations across EC2 instances. It is pre-configured with the necessary software, patches, and settings, enabling organizations to deploy EC2 instances with uniform configurations and security compliance.

Governance in AWS refers to the policies, controls, and practices that ensure resources and processes are managed according to organizational standards. It includes managing compliance, security, cost controls, and best practices for resource allocation and management.

A GPU is a processor designed for handling complex graphics and computational tasks, particularly useful in applications that require highperformance parallel processing, such as gaming, machine learning, and video rendering. AWS offers GPU instances for such use cases.

GPU Instances are EC2 instances that are optimized for graphics processing and computational tasks requiring high performance. These instances are ideal for workloads like deep learning, rendering, scientific simulations, and other GPU-intensive applications.

A Grant in AWS refers to the permissions given to a user, group, or role to access specific resources or actions. Grants are often managed through AWS IAM policies and roles, defining what actions are allowed on which AWS resources.

Grant Permissions refers to the temporary or explicit permissions assigned to a user, group, or role that allow access to specific AWS resources. These permissions are typically managed through IAM policies and can be modified or revoked as needed.

Granular Access Control allows fine-grained permission settings that provide precise control over user access to AWS resources. This includes specifying which actions can be performed on particular resources at the level of individual APIs or data operations, ensuring security and least-privilege access.

A Greenfield Deployment refers to setting up new AWS infrastructure with no existing dependencies or pre-existing setup. It contrasts with Brownfield Deployment, where AWS resources are added or modified to an existing infrastructure.

AWS Greengrass is a service that extends AWS IoT capabilities to local devices. It enables edge computing, allowing devices to run AWS Lambda functions, execute machine learning models, and store data locally, which is ideal for environments with intermittent internet connectivity.

A Group Policy in AWS IAM refers to a set of policies that are assigned to an IAM group, and these policies govern the permissions granted to all users within the group. It simplifies user permission management by applying a consistent set of rules to a collection of users.

terms.term: Grouping of Resources: In AWS CloudWatch Metrics, a
terms.definition: Namespace is used to organize and categorize different sets of metrics for efficient management. For example, all metrics related to a particular AWS service, like Amazon EC2, are grouped under its respective namespace. Identifier for AWS Services: A Namespace also serves as an identifier in CloudWatch Metrics to distinguish data originating from different AWS services. This allows users to track and analyze metrics specific to each service without overlap.

Amazon GuardDuty is a threat detection service that continuously monitors AWS accounts and workloads for malicious activity. It identifies threats such as unusual API calls, unauthorized access attempts, and compromised instances, helping administrators respond quickly to security risks.

Guardrails are predefined security and compliance controls that enforce AWS best practices. They are implemented through AWS Organizations and AWS Config to ensure resources are configured securely and in line with organizational policies and regulatory requirements.

Guest Access refers to providing limited or temporary access to AWS resources for users outside an AWS account. It is often used for crossaccount collaboration, allowing external stakeholders to access specific resources without granting full account access.

HAProxy is a widely used, open-source software for load balancing and proxying. It distributes incoming network traffic across multiple servers to ensure availability and reliability. In AWS, HAProxy can be used for custom routing of traffic, often for advanced use cases or to implement specific routing logic not covered by Elastic Load Balancing (ELB).

A Hardened Instance is an EC2 instance that has been securely configured to minimize vulnerabilities and prevent unauthorized access. This involves steps like disabling unused ports, applying patches, restricting access to only authorized users, and enforcing strong authentication mechanisms.

Hardware Acceleration refers to the use of specialized hardware components, such as Graphics Processing Units (GPUs) or Field Programmable Gate Arrays (FPGAs), to speed up processing tasks. In AWS, hardware acceleration is typically utilized for applications involving machine learning, scientific computation, and video rendering to achieve improved performance.

A Hardware Security Module (HSM) is a physical device that manages and safeguards digital keys for strong encryption. AWS CloudHSM provides managed HSM appliances that allow customers to create and control their own encryption keys, ensuring high levels of security for sensitive data in cloud applications.

A Hashing Algorithm is a mathematical function that converts input data of any size into a fixed-length output, typically known as a hash. This process is used in security applications for tasks like data integrity verification, password storage, and digital signatures. Common algorithms include SHA256 and MD5.

Hazard Detection refers to the identification of potential risks or vulnerabilities in applications or systems. AWS offers various security tools, such as Amazon Inspector and AWS GuardDuty, to automatically detect hazards like vulnerabilities, misconfigurations, or malicious activity in applications running in the cloud.

A Health Check is a process used by services like Amazon Route 53 and Elastic Load Balancing (ELB) to verify the availability and performance of resources, such as EC2 instances. If an instance fails a health check, it is marked as unhealthy, and traffic is routed to healthy instances, ensuring high availability.

Health Event Notifications are alerts generated by Amazon CloudWatch that notify administrators of changes in the health of AWS resources, such as EC2 instances, databases, or services. These notifications can help identify and address issues proactively, ensuring system reliability.

Health Monitoring involves continuously tracking the health and performance of system components, typically managed through Amazon CloudWatch. Monitoring key metrics such as CPU utilization, memory usage, and disk I/O helps maintain optimal performance and quickly detect potential issues.

Hibernation is a feature in AWS EC2 that allows instances to be paused and later resumed from the exact state they were in when hibernated. This allows users to save on instance costs while maintaining the ability to resume work without needing to fully restart the instance.

High Availability (HA) refers to the design of systems to ensure minimal downtime and continuous operation, even during failures. In AWS, HA is typically achieved by using redundant resources, such as multiple availability zones, load balancing, and failover strategies, ensuring that applications remain available even in case of hardware or software failures.

High Data Throughput refers to the ability of a system to process large volumes of data quickly. This is essential for use cases in data analytics, machine learning, and real-time data processing. AWS services like Amazon Kinesis and AWS Lambda can be used to handle high-throughput applications that require rapid data ingestion and processing.

High I/O Instances are EC2 instances optimized for applications that require high input/output operations, such as databases or data-intensive applications. These instances are designed to handle workloads that involve frequent access to disk storage, offering improved performance for I/O-intensive tasks. High Performance Computing (HPC) High Performance Computing (HPC) refers to the use of powerful computing resources for complex, data-intensive tasks such as simulations, scientific research, and big data analytics. In AWS, EC2 instances with specialized hardware configurations, such as GPUs or FPGAs, can be used for HPC workloads to deliver high computational performance.

High-Frequency Trading (HFT) is a specialized financial trading strategy that uses complex algorithms and low-latency infrastructure to execute high volumes of trades in fractions of a second. In AWS, low-latency EC2 instances are often used to run HFT algorithms, as they offer the performance necessary to meet the stringent speed and reliability requirements of HFT applications.

Horizontal Scaling involves adding or removing instances (or servers) to handle varying levels of demand. In AWS, Auto Scaling can automatically scale the number of EC2 instances up or down based on traffic demand or load, enabling applications to handle changes in load dynamically.

Host Resource Groups are collections of dedicated hosts in AWS that are grouped together for managing high-availability requirements across multiple regions. This setup helps manage workloads that need to be placed on physical servers, often used for regulatory compliance or licensing restrictions.

Hosted Directory is a service offered by AWS Directory Service that provides a fully managed Microsoft Active Directory. It allows you to integrate your AWS environment with existing Microsoft Active Directory resources or set up a new directory in the cloud to manage users, groups, and other directory-related tasks.

A Hosted VPC is a Virtual Private Cloud (VPC) that is hosted by AWS but isolated from other VPCs. It allows customers to run their resources (such as EC2 instances and databases) in a secure, private environment, making it easier to control network traffic, security settings, and resource isolation. Hosted Zone A Hosted Zone in Amazon Route 53 is a DNS zone that contains information about domain names and resource records. It is used to manage domain name resolution and routing for AWS resources, providing a scalable and reliable DNS service for applications hosted in AWS.

Hot Standby is a redundancy model in which a backup system is continuously running and ready to take over in the event of a failure of the primary system. This model ensures minimal downtime, as the backup instance is already online and can immediately assume operations when needed.

Hot Storage refers to storage systems designed for frequently accessed data. Amazon S3 Standard is an example of hot storage optimized for low-latency access and high durability. It is ideal for active data that needs to be retrieved and updated regularly, such as user data, logs, and application files.

An HTTP API is a low-cost, lightweight option in Amazon API Gateway for building HTTP-based APIs for web applications. It provides essential features like RESTful routing and supports authentication and authorization mechanisms to integrate securely with backend services.

HTTP Header Injection is a type of attack where malicious content is injected into HTTP headers, potentially leading to security vulnerabilities like crosssite scripting (XSS) or redirect attacks. AWS WAF (Web Application Firewall) offers protection against such attacks by filtering harmful input and preventing malicious HTTP headers from being processed.

Hybrid Architecture is an IT setup that combines both on-premises infrastructure and cloud resources, allowing for flexible and scalable resource management. In AWS, hybrid architectures enable workloads to be distributed across on-premises and cloud environments, offering the benefits of both.

A Hybrid Cloud is a computing environment that integrates on-premises infrastructure with cloud resources, allowing businesses to leverage both onsite data centers and cloud services like AWS. It enables businesses to run applications across environments, improving scalability, cost-efficiency, and flexibility.

Hybrid Networking refers to a network architecture that connects onpremises networks to AWS cloud resources using technologies like AWS VPN or AWS Direct Connect. It allows businesses to extend their internal networks into the cloud, enabling seamless communication between onpremises resources and cloud services.

Hybrid Storage is a combination of cloud-based and on-premises storage systems. It is often used in data migration scenarios, where data is transferred from on-premises systems to cloud storage like Amazon S3 or Amazon EBS, or for backup and disaster recovery purposes.

Hyper-Threading is a technology used in some EC2 instances that allows multiple threads to be processed simultaneously on a single physical CPU core. This feature improves the performance of multi-threaded applications by enabling better utilization of CPU resources.

A Hypervisor is a software layer that enables the virtualization of physical hardware, allowing multiple virtual machines (VMs) to run on a single physical host. AWS uses a hypervisor for its EC2 instances to enable efficient resource allocation and isolation between different virtual machines.

IAM is a service in AWS that allows administrators to manage user access to AWS resources securely. It provides the ability to create and manage users, groups, and roles and set permissions to control access to services like EC2, S3, and RDS. IAM helps ensure that only authorized users and services can access your resources.

IAM Policies are JSON documents that define the permissions associated with IAM users, groups, or roles. These policies specify which actions are allowed or denied on specific AWS resources. Policies can be managed by AWS or custom-defined, providing fine-grained access control to AWS services.

An IAM Role is a set of permissions that define what actions an AWS resource can perform. Roles are typically assigned to AWS services, EC2 instances, or other resources that need to perform actions on your behalf without requiring long-term access credentials like IAM users.

An IAM User is an individual account within AWS that represents a person or service with its own unique set of credentials and permissions. Users can be assigned to specific groups or roles, and their permissions define what resources they can access and what actions they can perform.

Identity Federation allows users to access AWS resources using credentials from an external identity provider (IdP) like Google, Facebook, or corporate Active Directory. AWS IAM can be configured to trust these external providers for temporary access via SAML, OAuth, or Cognito.

An Identity Pool is a feature in AWS Cognito that provides temporary access to AWS resources for authenticated or unauthenticated users. It allows developers to assign different permissions based on user authentication status, facilitating access control for mobile and web applications.

An Identity Provider (IdP) is a service that manages user identities and can be integrated with AWS for federated access. AWS supports a variety of IdPs, including corporate Active Directory, Google, and social login services, to authenticate users and grant them access to AWS resources.

Image Builder is an AWS service that automates the creation and management of machine images (AMIs) used for EC2 instances. It allows users to automate the process of building, testing, and distributing EC2 images, ensuring they are up to date and secure.

An In-Memory Database stores data in the server's RAM (Random Access Memory) rather than on disk, enabling faster data access. AWS services like Amazon ElastiCache and Amazon MemoryDB for Redis are used to accelerate performance in applications that require real-time data access.

An Inbound Rule is a security rule in Security Groups that defines which types of incoming traffic are allowed to reach a particular AWS resource, such as an EC2 instance. These rules specify the allowed IP addresses, ports, and protocols for inbound connections.

Indexing refers to the process of organizing data to make it easier and faster to search and retrieve. In services like Amazon DynamoDB, indexing is used to optimize query performance by creating additional queryable attributes that can speed up data retrieval.

Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS) is a cloud computing model where cloud providers deliver virtualized computing resources, such as storage, compute, and networking, over the internet. AWS provides IaaS with services like EC2 (for compute) and S3 (for storage), allowing businesses to avoid managing physical hardware.

Infrastructure as Code (IaC) is the practice of managing and provisioning computing infrastructure through code rather than manual processes. Using services like AWS CloudFormation and tools like Terraform, IaC enables developers to define infrastructure configurations, ensuring consistency and repeatability.

Infrequent Access Storage is an Amazon S3 storage class designed for data that is accessed less frequently but still needs to be readily available. This storage option offers lower costs for infrequent access data, such as backups and older archives, while still providing high durability and availability.

Ingress refers to incoming data or traffic directed at AWS resources, such as data entering an S3 bucket or traffic coming to an EC2 instance. It is used to define network traffic entering a system or application.

Ingress Rules are security rules in Security Groups that specify which incoming traffic is allowed to reach AWS resources. These rules define the source, protocol, port range, and IP address of incoming traffic to ensure that only authorized access is allowed.

Amazon Inspector is an automated security assessment service that helps identify vulnerabilities in applications and EC2 instances. It provides insights into potential security issues like missing patches, network configurations, and exposure to common threats, enabling faster remediation.

Instance Capacity Reservation is a feature in AWS that allows you to reserve EC2 capacity in a specific availability zone for future use. This ensures that the required compute resources are available when needed, which is especially useful for applications with predictable demand.

The Instance Life Cycle refers to the different phases of an EC2 instance's existence, which include launch, run, stop, terminate, and potential hibernation. Understanding the life cycle helps manage instances efficiently and optimize costs.

Instance Metadata refers to information about an EC2 instance that is available from within the instance itself. This includes details like the instance ID, public IP, instance type, and associated security groups. It can be accessed programmatically by EC2 applications.

An Instance Profile is an IAM role attached to an EC2 instance that grants it permission to perform specific actions on AWS resources. For example, an instance profile may grant an EC2 instance permission to access an S3 bucket or write to CloudWatch Logs. Instance State Instance State refers to the current operational status of an EC2 instance. Common instance states include running, stopped, and terminated. These states help monitor the health and lifecycle of EC2 instances.

Instance Store provides temporary storage directly attached to EC2 instances. The data stored in the instance store is lost if the instance is stopped or terminated. It is often used for storing temporary or non-persistent data that doesn't require durability.

Amazon S3 Intelligent-Tiering is a storage class that automatically moves data between two access tiers: frequent access and infrequent access. It optimizes storage costs by analyzing access patterns and transitioning data between tiers based on usage without requiring any manual intervention.
